Situation1: They send an occasional text to check in with their parents over the weekend.
Expectation2: Follow safety protocols to prevent accidents and injuries on site
Situation2: Before starting structural work, the carpenter needs to inspect and maintain tools and equipment to ensure safety and efficiency
Story: I stood in the workshop early Saturday morning, the scent of sawdust thick in the air. My hands moved automatically, checking the teeth of the circular saw, tightening bolts, making sure every tool was in perfect condition before the crew arrived. Safety was everything here—one mistake, one overlooked detail, and someone could get hurt. My mind ticked through the checklist, but my phone buzzed in my pocket, a reminder of another world. It was my mom, just a simple “How are you?” text, but I knew she expected more than a quick reply. She wanted to hear from me, to know I was okay, to feel that connection we promised to keep up every weekend. I felt the weight of the wrench in my hand and the weight of her expectations pressing on my chest. If I stopped now to call her, I’d lose focus, maybe miss something important in the inspection. But if I waited, I’d be letting her down again, making her worry. The noise of the shop faded as I stood there, torn between the safety of my team and the comfort of my family, not sure which role needed me more in that moment.
